Kindergartners at Primary Village North are learning that the word “attribute” is used to describe an object’s features, such as size, shape or color, which is then used to group it with similar objects. To help remember this, students watched a lesson about how to describe a shoe and were challenged by their teachers to get their own shoe and describe it to someone in their house. These two cousins wrote out their attributes and drew a picture to match!

Centerville High School marketing students have been getting to know each other better through branding and Zoom presentations!

Senior students selected a brand in which they have established brand loyalty to research trade names, brand names and brandmarks. They will then move their focus to corporate social responsibility and company core values.

Junior students created a slide to introduce themselves to their marketing peers. Their presentations included their hero, their happy place, a favorite brand and the trade character that best represents them. The junior class will soon be learning about the marketing mix and market segmentation. Two juniors from Oakwood High School are part of the class this school year.

Marketing is part of the Career Education Program, which is a collaborative effort between Centerville, Kettering and Oakwood High Schools that offers 18 distinct programs for juniors and seniors.

This site includes:
- A weekly menu of learning possibilities for each grade K-5
- Reading websites and apps
- Book lists appropriate for each grade
- Math websites, games, and activities
- Learning extensions
- Links to articles with tips for parents

Suzanne Crump has always wanted to have her first grade students participate in project-based learning by raising baby birds. An opportunity to raise North American Bobwhite Quail presented itself this spring, but with school buildings closed, the question became how she could involve her students through remote learning.

These young students from PVS have been able to participate in virtual discussions with experts, write about their research, share what they’ve learned with each other on Flipgrid, and figure out how to measure, describe and draw what a quail egg looks like – all from the safety of their homes!

“No virus will stop our love for thinking and learning,” Crump said. “This project gives us a way to shine some love, kindness, peace and compassion – just what we need right now.”

Read more: https://bit.ly/2TkOjGO

The Centerville High School Culinary Arts program competed in the annual ProStart Invitational. Although this year’s competition was not quite the same since it was held virtually, students still worked hard to submit their projects. Here are a few pictures of food projects, as well as some of the graphics from the Management team’s business proposal for their restaurant concept, “Foodology.” Students will find out in the coming weeks how they finished.

Teacher Mr. Mitrovich said, “In these times of trying to keep students focused, it was encouraging to see these kids stick with their project and pull together a great example of Elk pride!”

Culinary Arts is part of the Career Education Program, which is a collaborative effort between Centerville, Kettering and Oakwood High Schools that offers 18 distinct programs for juniors and seniors.

Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine announced today that the closure of K-12 school buildings in Ohio would be extended for the remainder of the school year. Our teachers will continue the remote learning we have in place through the end of this school year on May 28 (May 20 for seniors).

We know this has placed a heavy burden on all of you, and we appreciate the support and dedication to helping provide the best educational opportunities possible to our students during this unprecedented time.

We will continue to communicate updates to our families and staff members through our website (www.centerville.k12.oh.us/coronavirus), The Education Connection phone system and email notification from individual teachers, schools and the district.

We know this has placed a heavy burden on all of you, and we appreciate the support and dedication to helping provide the best educational opportunities possible to our students during this unprecedented time.

We will continue to communicate updates to our families and staff members through our website (www.centerville.k12.oh.us/coronavirus), The Education Connection phone system and email notification from individual teachers, schools and the district.

Centerville High School students in the Information Technology/Software Engineering career education program compete each year in an IT expo hosted by the School of Information Technology at the University of Cincinnati. This expo showcases projects by students in UC’s undergraduate and graduate level IT programs, as well as projects by high school students, applied research centers and industry.

Because of the current health emergency, this year’s public event was changed to an online one. Congratulations to the three CHS teams that qualified to compete in yesterday’s Virtual #ITExpo20! During the live event, visitors could navigate virtually through different project rooms, watch videos provided by the student groups that explained or demonstrated their projects, and even ask student teams questions about their work.

IT/Software Engineering is part of the Career Education Program, which is a collaborative effort between Centerville, Kettering and Oakwood High Schools that offers 18 distinct programs for juniors and seniors.

Mrs. Marshall, an English language arts teacher at Watts Middle School, is encouraging her students to stay positive during these challenging times. She created a BINGO sheet with items in five categories: Brain Benefits, Icons, Notes, Good for You and Outside. Students chose five boxes to complete a BINGO that would help make their week better, took pictures and wrote about them for class. Some of the ideas included reading an article on Newsela, using common household objects to recreate the peace sign symbol, writing a thank you note to a specific first responder, playing a board game with someone in your house, or doing something active outside.

For the past couple of weeks, seventh graders in Mrs. Stanley’s English language arts class at Tower Heights Middle School have been hard at work on STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics) projects related to the novel “Phoenix Rising” by Karen Hesse. Each student could use a variety of tools, such as Ozobot robot, Makey-Makey invention kits, 3D printer, Legos, websites and more, to create three projects focused on a setting, character and the novel itself, with at least one being interactive. This week, they presented their completed work to their classmates.

These Makey-Makey invention kits were part of a Centerville Education Foundation grant that Mrs. Stanley received this year. These versatile tech tools were used by some students with Scratch.com to create interactive plot lines and posters. Students recorded required information on Scratch, built a circuit board with copper tape, brads and cardboard, and assembled the Makey-Makey kits so that when touched, the posters would say information automatically.

Julie Edsall spoke with eighth graders at Watts Middle School this morning about Honor Flight, which transports U.S. military veterans to Washington, D.C., to see the memorials of the respective wars in which they fought, at no cost to the veterans. Mrs. Edsall has participated on two of these flights, one with her father and another as a volunteer.

In their English language arts classes, students will be writing letters to veterans who attend the next Honor Flight in the spring. As part of her presentation, Mrs. Edsall showed the eighth graders a scrapbook with sample letters and talked about how emotional the veterans are as they read the letters and cards from family, friends and students.

Congratulations to Centerville High School students Deklin Caban, Alison Hardie, Auggie Harner, Shriya Rangaswamy and William Zhang, who recently won the Penguin Bowl, a regional ocean science academic competition that is part of the National Ocean Sciences Bowl (NOSB)!

The Penguin Bowl, which was hosted by the Pittsburgh Zoo and PPG Aquarium and co-hosted by Youngstown State University, is part of a nationwide competition that tests students’ knowledge of ocean science disciplines through buzzer-style, multiple-choice questions and open-ended team challenge questions. The CHS team will join winners from 22 other regional bowls April 16-19 in Mississippi for the NOSB Finals.

“Winning this tournament is a really incredible feat, given that we are a landlocked area and our high school does not offer advanced courses in oceanography nor marine biology,” said Mrs. Manfredi, one of the team coaches. “This really speaks to the work ethic, tenacity and insatiable desire for knowledge that these students have.”

Another CHS team took second place in the regional competition.

#ElkPride

Since 1923, Scholastic Art and Writing awards have honored young artists whose work demonstrates technical skill, originality and emergence of a personal voice or vision.

Recently, 14 artworks from Centerville High School artists were selected from more than 1,500 regional entries to be honored and displayed at the regional level at K12 Gallery and TEJAS. Artworks by four students – Ella McDowell, Sophie Winslow, Avery Hick and Kayla Feng were awarded with Gold Key honors, which means their work will go on to national competition for the chance to win honors among the most promising artists in the nation. Kayla and Sophie’s work also received two of the five American Visions Awards, signifying the top five juried pieces from the 400 piece show. In addition Avery, Kayla and Amir Al-Barqawi received silver and/or honorable mentions for their work.

We are so proud of all of our artists for their daily work to develop individual visual voices!

Seventh grade students in Mrs. Stanley’s English language arts class at Tower Heights Middle School participated in a panel debate today!

They began their research with a quick-write on current energy usage in the United States. They then met with Mrs. Kibby, the ELA curriculum coach, to learn how to follow and evaluate an argument by using mentor texts, such as Greta Thunberg’s speech from this fall’s U.N. Climate Action Summit.

Students’ critical thinking skills were tested as they got into “energy expert” pairs, representing a variety of energy sources, to evaluate claims and take into account potential counterclaims.

The project culminated in 5-minute presentations where a student U.N. panel tracked their use of ethos (gaining audience trust), pathos (appealing to their emotions), and logos (targeting logic with facts).

Seven English language arts classes at Magsig Middle School have been studying the Holocaust. The eighth grade classes decided to do something special to remember those who were personally affected by the atrocities that occurred during this time period.

Each student read biographical sketches of people who were taken from their homes and sent to concentration camps. Then, they selected a person whose story “spoke to them” and wrote the person’s name, country and whether or not they survived on an index card. This morning, as part of International Holocaust Remembrance Day, the classes gathered in the auditorium for a special memorial.
